story:
“I want to be around people that do things. I don’t want to be around people anymore that judge or talk about what people do. I want to be around people that dream and support and do things.” - Amy Poehler 

The main reason I want to do this project is there are not enough women getting recognition in comedy or the industry in general.

Why focus on working with women? Did you know the Center for the Study of Women in Television and Film found that in the top 100 grossing films of 2018, women represented:

  • 4% of directors
  • 15% of writers
  • 3% of cinematographers
  • 18% of producers
  • 18% of executive producers
  • 14% of editors

I want to try to do my bit to change this and get women from all different backgrounds trained with comedy skills, get them into writing or performing comedy and working alongside others doing the same. 

Who am I?

Hi, I’m Jane. I’m a Cumbrian Comedy Performer and Writer. I'm a comedy award finalist for Funny Women, Brighton Comedy Festival and best comedy show at Brighton Fringe. 

My experience includes running a successful comedy night called the ‘Bad Book Project’ in Brighton, being on BBC Radio 4 in a couple of comedy plays and producing the ‘Miraculous Cumbria Podcast’ a comedy podcast about interesting locations/events in Cumbria with my co-host Steph Bradshaw.

Over the last five years I’ve written five brand new one hour comedy shows including ‘Made in Cumbria’ and ‘The House’. Three solo Character comedy shows, one theatrical / stand up show about mental health and suicide awareness - plus one recent sketch show called ‘HAUNTED’ with my new comedy writing/podcast partner Steph Bradshaw. I have taken all five shows to Brighton Fringe and two to Edinburgh Fringe Festival.

Alongside my own comedy work, I run comedy workshops across the UK and abroad. My workshops include comedy writing, creating characters and performing.

In Manchester, I focus on women’s comedy workshops where I’ve met so many talented women wanting to do sketch, stand up, comedy videos and more. I also set up the Cumbria School of Comedy to make comedy workshops accessible to people in rural areas. I've taught over 250 people in just a couple of years. 

My students have already started stand up comedy, written/performed their own one hour comedy shows, filming sketches and more. I want them to have the opportunity to get involved in this new project. 

I also want to make use of my previous scripts from my comedy shows and get them recorded as a podcast in the style of a BBC Radio comedy drama. 

Why a podcast?

I know from experience that putting on live shows is very expensive and time consuming especially at the fringe festivals. Making a podcast cuts costs compared to putting on a live show as the sketches and characters can be set anywhere e.g, in space and you don't need props or costume.

Recording a podcast is also flexible as you have portable equipment and can set up remotely. Also, not everyone can always make it to watch comedy shows live so by doing a comedy podcast the work becomes accessible as you can listen for free while on the move and from anywhere in the World.

Why is it called Character Building?

The podcast will be made up of character sketches and monologues. Also, the double meaning is that growing up in the North people tell you anything challenging is 'Character building'! 

What do we need?

The money I want to raise for the project in the Crowdfunder is around £4000 and will pay for;

  • Updated recording equipment for portable recording and a home studio
  • Rehearsal studio time in Manchester
  • Recording time in a professional studio in Manchester
  • Travel costs and lunch for contributors in Manchester - up to 25 women involved
  • Travel and meet up costs for anyone outside of Manchester
  • Extra Training sessions for me and for contributors
  • Merchandise like badges / stickers to help promote
  • Marketing and promotion of podcast
  • Graphic Design
  • A years subscription to Audioboom to host the podcast
  • Website costs and domain name

Podcast Equipment and some of the other costs estimated;

  • x2 Microphones £300
  • x2 Portable Audio booths / Kaotica Eyeballs £400
  • x2 Microphone cords £40
  • Mixing desk £150
  • Microphone stands £50
  • x2 Script stands £40
  • x2 Microphone stands £70
  • Audioboom £120 a year
  • Website £120 a year and domain name
  • Voice Over Training
  • Travel for contributors train or petrol + lunch £40 per person (x20 people) £800
  • Unlimited training for each contributor if needed £50 per person (x20 people) £1000
  • Recording Studio space rental £110 an hour Manchester
  • Writing studio £100 a day
  • Marketing / Merch - badges £100

Women involved will get some or all of the following;

  • Free training in writing sketches either working alone or as a team at the studio space
  • Get their sketches chosen for the podcast and get a writing credit
  • Get voice acting credits performing sketches
  • Free travel
  • Free lunch
  • Free training on how to use podcasting equipment
  • Shown what it's like to record in a professional studio
  • Their work recorded and available on iTunes, Spotify and Google Podcasts
  • Name mentioned in any press articles / website credits

Wherever they're based the women can still contribute. Some women might only want to submit a sketch or monologue by email. Some may want to meet as a group for training, to share ideas and write as a team. I'll be doing my best to include as many women as possible who have done my workshop.

The 27 women wanting to be involved so far are:

  • Alexandra Nicole Stringer
  • Ruth Postlethwaite
  • Charlene Coulter-Clements
  • Sarah Fordham
  • Rachel Robbins
  • Louisa Bennett
  • Jo Gendle 
  • Catherine Lee
  • Lizzie Norm
  • Ruqayyah Hashmi
  • Lorraine Helen Youds
  • Anna Lloyd
  • Hannah Fox
  • Sophie White
  • Abigail Ramsdale
  • Michelle Taylor
  • Nicola Brockbank
  • Mel Judson
  • Phoebe Farrington
  • Nadine Graba
  • Laura Stoney
  • Lynsey McQuaid
  • Sho Applewood 
  • Katy Holbird
  • Eleanor Bronwen Appleton

What I will be overseeing the whole project;

  • Converting scripts from 'Made in Cumbria' and 'The House' into radio scripts
  • Writing & Editing 'HAUNTED' with Steph Bradshaw 
  • Producing
  • Directing
  • Training for writing scripts and working with audio
  • Editing work from contributors 
  • Editing the podcast
  • Marketing
  • Training myself in Voice over skills and keeping up with editing / recording skills
  • Launching the podcast on iTune, Spotify and Google Podcast

Who else is involved?

Steph Bradshaw - Exec Producer of Character Building. Co-host of Miraculous Cumbria and Co-Writer/Performer in the sketch show HAUNTED. Steph will be co-editing, converting HAUNTED to script for recording and recording the show. Also, writing new material and performing whilst over seeing production and assisting marketing. 

The plan is I'm aiming for 6-8 episodes of 20 mins over the next 6 - 12 months. The timeline for the project involves;

  • Getting equipment ready
  • Training gained
  • Comedy submissions received
  • Group sessions organised in rehearsal space
  • Submissions edited
  • Roles allocated for cast
  • Recording sessions in home studio or Manchester studio
  • Marketing and Promotion
  • Season edited and put live
  • More promotion

The Impact - Helping get more women involved in Comedy!

  • Letting me share my previous fringe shows as free comedy episodes
  • Getting my previous students involved in writing and recording
  • Including women who live in rural areas, who have busy lives with jobs and children or money constrictions 
  • FREE training for female students on the way a podcast is put together / voice over performing / podcast production / script editing skills
  • Letting women pitch sketches for the podcast
  • Building skill sets and confidence in others
  • Days in studio recording and working on scripts
  • Giving myself and students comedy credits
  • Training myself so i can pass on knowledge to others
  • Opportunities for future collaboration and season two.

Risks & Challenges

  • Getting awareness of the crowdfunder - we need people to share the love to bring awareness to the campaign. Social media shares will help and private emails. 
  • Not getting the full amount - if we don't get the full amount of money it will be spent on most important things first like training and for the women to have free travel to make the training accessible
  • Not having enough money for the new podcasting equipment - key equipment from the list will be bought first 
  • £4000 is a goal to train 20-25 women - the more funding we get the more women it can benefit in the long run. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can’t help financially you can still help us make some noise about the campaign by sharing with friends and family.
  • Also, please use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign on social media!
  • Are you a business who runs a recording studio or rehearsal space? You can help by donating free rental time. 
  • Are you a business or individual who wants to sponsor an episode? See the perks. 
  • We will also accept any sponsorship for notebooks, pens, podcasting / recording equipment, food and drinks etc.

Also, the double meaning is that growing up in the North people tell you anything challenging is 'Character building'! What do we need?The money I want to raise for the project in the Crowdfunder is around £4000 and will pay for;
Updated recording equipment for portable recording and a home studio
Rehearsal studio time in Manchester
Recording time in a professional studio in Manchester
Travel costs and lunch for contributors in Manchester - up to 25 women involved
Travel and meet up costs for anyone outside of Manchester
Extra Training sessions for me and for contributors
Merchandise like badges / stickers to help promote
Marketing and promotion of podcast
Graphic Design
A years subscription to Audioboom to host the podcast
Website costs and domain name
Podcast Equipment and some of the other costs estimated;
x2 Microphones £300
x2 Portable Audio booths / Kaotica Eyeballs £400
x2 Microphone cords £40
Mixing desk £150
Microphone stands £50
x2 Script stands £40
x2 Microphone stands £70
Audioboom £120 a year
Website £120 a year and domain name
Voice Over Training
Travel for contributors train or petrol + lunch £40 per person (x20 people) £800
Unlimited training for each contributor if needed £50 per person (x20 people) £1000
Recording Studio space rental £110 an hour Manchester
Writing studio £100 a day
Marketing / Merch - badges £100
Women involved will get some or all of the following;
Free training in writing sketches either working alone or as a team at the studio space
Get their sketches chosen for the podcast and get a writing credit
Get voice acting credits performing sketches
Free travel
Free lunch
Free training on how to use podcasting equipment
Shown what it's like to record in a professional studio
Their work recorded and available on iTunes, Spotify and Google Podcasts
Name mentioned in any press articles / website credits
Wherever they're based the women can still contribute. Some women might only want to submit a sketch or monologue by email. Some may want to meet as a group for training, to share ideas and write as a team. I'll be doing my best to include as many women as possible who have done my workshop.The 27 women wanting to be involved so far are:
Alexandra Nicole Stringer
Ruth Postlethwaite
Charlene Coulter-Clements
Sarah Fordham
Rachel Robbins
Louisa Bennett
Jo Gendle 
Catherine Lee
Lizzie Norm
Ruqayyah Hashmi
Lorraine Helen Youds
Anna Lloyd
Hannah Fox
Sophie White
Abigail Ramsdale
Michelle Taylor
Nicola Brockbank
Mel Judson
Phoebe Farrington
Nadine Graba
Laura Stoney
Lynsey McQuaid
Sho Applewood 
Katy Holbird
Eleanor Bronwen Appleton
What I will be overseeing the whole project;
Converting scripts from 'Made in Cumbria' and 'The House' into radio scripts
Writing & Editing 'HAUNTED' with Steph Bradshaw 
Producing
Directing
Training for writing scripts and working with audio
Editing work from contributors 
Editing the podcast
Marketing
Training myself in Voice over skills and keeping up with editing / recording skills
Launching the podcast on iTune, Spotify and Google Podcast
Who else is involved?Steph Bradshaw - Exec Producer of Character Building. Co-host of Miraculous Cumbria and Co-Writer/Performer in the sketch show HAUNTED. Steph will be co-editing, converting HAUNTED to script for recording and recording the show. Also, writing new material and performing whilst over seeing production and assisting marketing. The plan is I'm aiming for 6-8 episodes of 20 mins over the next 6 - 12 months. The timeline for the project involves;
Getting equipment ready
Training gained
Comedy submissions received
Group sessions organised in rehearsal space
Submissions edited
Roles allocated for cast
Recording sessions in home studio or Manchester studio
Marketing and Promotion
Season edited and put live
More promotion
The Impact - Helping get more women involved in Comedy!
Letting me share my previous fringe shows as free comedy episodes
Getting my previous students involved in writing and recording
Including women who live in rural areas, who have busy lives with jobs and children or money constrictions 
FREE training for female students on the way a podcast is put together / voice over performing / podcast production / script editing skills
Letting women pitch sketches for the podcast
Building skill sets and confidence in others
Days in studio recording and working on scripts
Giving myself and students comedy credits
Training myself so i can pass on knowledge to others
Opportunities for future collaboration and season two.
Risks & Challenges
Getting awareness of the crowdfunder - we need people to share the love to bring awareness to the campaign. Social media shares will help and private emails. 
Not getting the full amount - if we don't get the full amount of money it will be spent on most important things first like training and for the women to have free travel to make the training accessible
Not having enough money for the new podcasting equipment - key equipment from the list will be bought first 
£4000 is a goal to train 20-25 women - the more funding we get the more women it can benefit in the long run. 
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can’t help financially you can still help us make some noise about the campaign by sharing with friends and family.
Also, please use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign on social media!
Are you a business who runs a recording studio or rehearsal space? You can help by donating free rental time. 
Are you a business or individual who wants to sponsor an episode? See the perks. 
We will also accept any sponsorship for notebooks, pens, podcasting / recording equipment, food and drinks etc.

story:
Who am I?

My name is Nshan Kesecker. I grew up in San Francisco, CA, where I attended KZV Armenian School from kindergarten through 8th grade, where I learned to read and write Armenian. I am also a deacon of the Armenian Apostolic Church. Birthright Armenia provided me with the incredible opportunity of interning at Yerevan State University's Department of Middle Eastern Studies. I took advantage of this opportunity and was eventually accepted as a PhD student and lecturer in the department. 

I started the Hayastan Podcast to be a show about everyday life in Armenia from various perspectives. I have been living in Armenia for a little over a year. Being involved as an active member of both a major Diasporan community as well as in several projects in Yerevan, it became apparent to me how much of a disconnect there is between Armenians from the Republic of Armenia and the Diaspora. 

What We Need & What You Get

As a PhD student and part-time lecturer, it is hard for me to keep the podcast going without the support of the community. I have received a lot of positive feedback as well as encouragement to expand the scope of the project, which is something I would very much like to do. In order to do that, I need your support. I can't provide physical rewards for your support, but I promise to keep the flow of content coming and continuously work to increase its quality.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know that not everyone can provide financial support, but continuously listening and sharing the content of the show to your friends and family makes a big impact.

story:
About Me

My name is James and I'm the creator and main host of Modern-Day Debate. I'm working on my PhD in organizational psychology and I LOVE debates & discussions.

We started Modern-Day Debate about 2 years ago because we wanted to ensure that people from all walks of life had a fully-neutral and fair platform they could make their case on, or hear other people make their case on!

We host debates on science, religion, and politics, because we believe debate has the potential to change cultures for the better by getting people with different perspectives to communicate, and to show that people can disagree and still be friends.

About This Event

We believe that this particular debate between atheist, Matt Dillahunty and Christian, Dr Kenny Rhodes will help people from all walks of life learn more about other perspectives as this debate will be live-streamed for the world to see (and remain on the Modern-Day Debate YouTube channel afterward).

Our Funding Plan:

We have an overall goal of $3,500 to make this event happen! Details are in our infographic below:

 

Our Perks:

We have a variety of perks including getting your name shouted out at the end of the debate during the thank you shout outs, getting a Modern-Day Debate embossed thank you postcard in the mail as a souvenir for this EPIC event, a meet & greet with the speakers prior to the debate, or a Modern-Day Debate t-shirt!

If we don't reach our goal, 100% of the donations are returned! If we pass our goal, we plan on using the extra funds for extra promotion (e.g., YouTube & Facebook ads) and putting the money toward the costs of another future epic debate!

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out by sharing this project with other people who love debates and intellectual ideas!

You can even use the convenient Indiegogo share tools!

Risks and Challenges

*Due to COVID concerns, this debate will be remote over Zoom. 

If you don't get what was promised, we promise a 100% refund on your donation. We want there to be zero risk for you, the audience. Therefore, if this event does not happen, everyone who donated at any tier gets 100% of their money back. 

Our own risk is whether or not we can raise the funds, as we do not want to contact the speakers (which we already have) and not make our goal of raising the funds to pay the honorariums we have promised. We are 100% determined to make this event happen!

story:
Short Summary

I'm Josh Combs, an artist and Star Wars fanatic. Me and my lifelong friend Stefan Spallino, who has probably been obsessed with Star Wars from the womb, are going to be getting loose and talking Star Wars every Wednesday night, along with a variety of guests. We will be providing the latest Star Wars news and rumors, we will be covering a variety of topics including deep character histories, movie breakdowns, animated series, video games, Star Wars Land, ridiculous and awesome fan theories, our own predictions for the future of the franchise and we will take a closer look at the history and making of the Star Wars Universe.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to keep the show interactive and entertaining, we would like to broadcast on video, possibly live. Currently, we are designing and building the set so we are forced to record audio-only episodes in the shed in my backyard. With your help, we can buy decent video and audio equipment and lighting.

As a fan of podcasts and Star Wars, we have noticed there are only a few who interact with their viewers and allow them to share their insight and love of Star Wars. Your participation in our crowdfunding campaign will benefit you as a viewer:

  • For a $1 donation you will recieve one free entry to our first monthly collectible toy giveaway. This month we are giving away one 6" Princess Leia Organa Black Series Figure, with her famous white robe and side buns from Episode 4 and (spoiler alert) The end of Rogue One.
  • For a $25 donation you will be featured on a segment of our Skype call-in show.
  • For a $100 donation you will have the chance to Skype in for an entire episode (1-2 hours) about absolutely anything you would like to talk about, as long as it is Star Wars.

Other Ways You Can Help

Like and Subscribe to Star Wars After Hours and Share our videos!

http://facebook.com/starwarsafterhourspodcast

https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/id1208499837

http://www.stitcher.com/s?fid=132122&refid=stpr

Instagram - @starwarsafterhours

Twitter - @swafterhours

http://www.starwarsafterhours.com

story:
Summary

Living Well with Mental Illness is a podcast focused on bringing to light some of the strategies that ease the burden of being afflicted with mental illness. The host, Chris Rauch, was first diagnosed with depression at age 19 and at 40 had his diagnosis modified to Bi-polar disorder type II. Chris will walk listeners through the reality of living with what is often a mis-understood illness. In an effort to break the stigma surrounding mental illness Chris will interview people with mental illness and talk frankly about daily living. Some of the interviewees will have found the strength and courage to live well while battling the emotional turmoil that is mental illness. Chris will focus on these strategies in an effort to share a message of hope with those people who are overwhelmed daily by trying to manage their illness.  Living Well with Mental Illness is also intended for the family and friends of people burdened with mental illness by providing the insights that will produce a positive impact in the lives of loved ones.

 

What I need

I need your help to launch this effort.  There are several ways that your assistance would be welcomed. 

  • Firstly, I am looking for volunteers or referrals of people that struggle with mental illness and would be willing to share their story. If possible I am looking for people like me that have found some strategies to manage daily life through self-care in addition to medical treatment.  This open dialogue will help podcast listeners feel less alone in their struggle and find hope for better days.
  • Secondly, I will gladly accept any help with online and social media marketing.  I am hoping to reach a large audience and that will take skills beyond what I currently possess. 
  • Thirdly, I could use a little financial support to help with hardware, software and web hosting costs.  I am asking for $3500 worth of support to cover start-up costs. 
  • Finally, If you’d like to help support the project, and aren’t in a position to help with any of the previously listed options, please send me an e-mail voicing your support.  I would love to hear your story and learn more about you.

 

The Impact

The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that 1-in-4 people globally struggle with mental illness.  I’d like to think that I can have an impact on 1.9 billion people but I recognize that might be too lofty of a goal. I suspect that the reality will be somewhere between 1 and 1.9B people will be impacted as a result of the podcast, Living Well with Mental Illness.  If I can give a handful of people the courage and strength to improve their daily self-care regime I’ll be a success.

 

Risks and Challenges

I’d be delusional if I thought this effort was free of risk and challenges.  Perhaps the most noteworthy challenge will be if Chris is having an emotionally down week and is unable to find the energy to record and edit a new episode of the podcast.  In an effort to alleviate this risk Chris has mapped out a schedule to ensure that 2-3 episodes are cued up for release at any given time so that there is a buffer and no pressure to record then publish a podcast in the same week.

The other significant risk is any potentially unforeseen backlash associated with “coming out” as mentally ill.  Very few of Chris’s friends know about his illness and at work he has contained the information to his manager and Director of HR.

 

Other Ways You Can Help 

If you aren’t in a position to donate, I understand. You can still help! I want to reach as many people as possible. Spread the word about my fundraising campaign on your social media account, help me identify people to interview for the podcast, or help in any way that your talents warrant – just send me (Chris) an e-mail and share with me your thoughts. 

 

Timeline

Looking ahead at my personal and work schedule I have devised the following schedule which is slightly aggressive but within reason.

01 January 2018 - Launch the Indiegogo Campaign

25 Jan 2018 - close the campaign (I need to go to sea for work and will be disconnected from the internet)

February 2018 - record and edit 6-8 podcast episodes

04 March 2018 - release the first podcast (Wednesday release of podcast, weekly thereafter)

story:
Help fund Fable Gazers, a boutique podcast company

 

Fable Gazers is Sara-Mae Tuson, a freelance editor/writer and aspiring YA author, and her friend and fellow freelancer, Beth Keehn.

Please back our campaign to help support our first two podcasts: The Sugar Baby Confessionals, interviews with a friend who chose the sugar baby lifestyle; and Heyer Today, a podcast about best-selling author, Georgette Heyer. 

We have lovely gifts for campaign supporters!

We need your help to get our fledgling podcast company off the ground.

Three reasons to back our campaign:

1. Hey, it’s Xmas time!

Tired of giving expensive yet lame Secret Santa gifts? Why not make your friend an Overnight Entrepreneur – support our campaign and we’ll send you a certificate you can print out and give your Secret Santa recipient.

2. Podcast percentage pothole

Did you know – only 22% of podcasts are hosted by women? Help us fill the percentage pothole! We will be delighted to improve the numbers with our many Fable Gazers tales – tall, true and otherwise – in the coming months.

3. Our podcasts will have:

  • high production values
  • original music
  • a new story to explore each season.

We have poured so much of our time, love and energy into collecting the best interviews, with the best people (did we mention that we spoke to legendary actor Stephen Fry!?).

Your support will help us fund production - writing, interviewing, recording and editing - a Libsyn account, a dedicated website and help us broaden our social media reach.

The podcasts you'll be supporting are:

FABLE GAZERS SERIES 1: THE SUGAR BABY CONFESSIONALS

                                  

 

This is a true story. Ruby is juggling family life with her new ‘job’ – as a sugar baby. Ruby has three small children and a husband she loves. Already enjoying an open relationship, she’s decided she wants to try being paid for doing something she’s reeeeeaally good at. What could possibly go wrong?

As her close friend, Sara-Mae helps Ruby process and explore the ups and downs of this alternative lifestyle choice. 

Highlights:

  • Lush original music from Danny Green of LAISH and the incredible Kristen MacClement. 
  • A special interview with The Brit - Ruby's favourite sugar daddy
  • Sex tips from a pro (well, Ruby)
  • Feminist psychology expert weighs in on the effects of being a sugar baby
  • Interviews with US-based sugar baby, Madelaine, on making the most out of your… assets

FABLE GAZERS SERIES 2: HEYER TODAY

Like many of you worldwide, we are major Georgette Heyer fans as well as being podcast junkies. With no existing podcast about Heyer’s work available, we decided to create our own. 

Over the course of our podcast, 'Heyer Today', we hope to convert new readers to her wonderful work, examine her influences and look at what was happening in Heyer’s life when she wrote her best-selling books. Also, with rumours of (finally!) a screen adaptation in 2018, we’ll also explore the mystery of why Heyer's work hasn’t been film franchised, chatting to a variety of experts, fans and celebrity guests.

Highlights:

  • Stephen Fry on how he came to be hooked on Heyer
  • Acclaimed Heyer biographer: Jennifer Kloester on the author’s life and times.
  • Producer Andy Paterson discusses a mystery project and the difficulties of bringing Heyer’s work to the screen
  • Romance novelist Harriet Evans lists her all-time favourites
  • Susannah Fullerton, head of the Jane Austen Society in Australia, compares Austen and Heyer
  • Author Jane Holland and literary agent Alison Bonami from LBA on Heyer’s greatest romantic heroes
  • Music from the incomparable Emma Gatrill
  • The beautiful Helen Rose-Davidge (pictured) playing Georgette Heyer in our teaser videos
  • **For donors only – audio scenes from the books hilariously recreated by Sara-Mae and her ‘converts’

Don’t forget to subscribe to our mailing list for more news, blogs and free stuff.

And please share this page with anyone you know who loves cool things.

Love you all!

Interviews with US-based sugar baby, Madelaine, on making the most out of your… assets
FABLE GAZERS SERIES 2: HEYER TODAYLike many of you worldwide, we are major Georgette Heyer fans as well as being podcast junkies. With no existing podcast about Heyer’s work available, we decided to create our own. Over the course of our podcast, 'Heyer Today', we hope to convert new readers to her wonderful work, examine her influences and look at what was happening in Heyer’s life when she wrote her best-selling books. Also, with rumours of (finally!) a screen adaptation in 2018, we’ll also explore the mystery of why Heyer's work hasn’t been film franchised, chatting to a variety of experts, fans and celebrity guests.Highlights:
Stephen Fry on how he came to be hooked on Heyer
Acclaimed Heyer biographer: Jennifer Kloester on the author’s life and times.
Producer Andy Paterson discusses a mystery project and the difficulties of bringing Heyer’s work to the screen
Romance novelist Harriet Evans lists her all-time favourites
Susannah Fullerton, head of the Jane Austen Society in Australia, compares Austen and Heyer
Author Jane Holland and literary agent Alison Bonami from LBA on Heyer’s greatest romantic heroes
Music from the incomparable Emma Gatrill
The beautiful Helen Rose-Davidge (pictured) playing Georgette Heyer in our teaser videos
**For donors only – audio scenes from the books hilariously recreated by Sara-Mae and her ‘converts’
Don’t forget to subscribe to our mailing list for more news, blogs and free stuff.And please share this page with anyone you know who loves cool things.Love you all!

story:
We’ve Only Just Begun…

Atlanta Theatre Life needs new equipment!.

One year ago, I began the process of getting this small dream up and running by hosting a fundraiser on Indiegogo. After some significant personal set-backs, Atlanta Theatre Life launched in October 2017. We’re only 19 episodes in, and the response has been phenomenal! I’m truly grateful to everyone for listening and offering support.

The podcast has been a wonderful experience and I am having so much fun getting to speak with so many amazing people that make up Atlanta’s vibrant theatre community. But the fun is also time-consuming, and most assuredly not free. I’m currently borrowing some of the equipment for recording purposes and would like to return it to their rightful owners. The program also has host-site costs paid monthly to our wonderful partners at Audioboom.

Additionally, I’m looking to expand the scope of our programming by hosting group conversations and town halls with industry leaders and field specialists to help shine a light on broader topics of discussion within our community.

ALL THIS TO SAY ----

If you enjoy the program and would like to contribute to its continued growth and success, please consider a donation via this Indiegogo Campaign!

Think of it like an NPR Fund Drive; your financial contribution helps cover the costs of creating and producing this show. A little bit goes a long way!

And if you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

You can help get the word out about Atlanta Theatre Life and this Indiegogo Campaign. Share links via all your social media outlets. And don’t forget to subscribe to the program wherever you listen to podcasts!

Thanks so much for listening,

Later Lifers.

story:
PLEASE VISIT OUR NEW WEBSITE AT: 

WWW.THREETOKENBROWNGIRLS.COM

Background

In September 2017, Sammie, a badass woman of color, decided to start a Facebook page because she wanted a place where she could have a voice and be heard. In her words, “a place where I could reach more people and not be spoken over or silenced. I wanted to be able to provide education to privileged people and help them unpack their biases”.  She started the page by naming it “Sammie the Token Brown Girl” and began her journey to creating these safe spaces for others. Before creating the page, Sammie held an important Facebook presence in various Facebook groups as someone who was committed to advocating for others who traditionally have been without a voice in greater the conversation around social injustices. She was known for tirelessly educating others on feminist issues, issues of racism, and so much more. She has been a trusted person for a lot of people, which is what has lead to such a popular following of her page. Shortly after starting her page, she decided to bring on two other women of color, Chiany and Erica, to bring in other important perspectives on the experiences of women of color. The name of the page was quickly changed to “Three Token Brown Girls”, and together, the three of them built a following of over 3,000 people who supported their work and their voices.

 

Why Starting this Podcast is Important

We’ve learned that through stories and personal connection, we all learn the most about compassion, and this is why supporting our podcast is truly important. At the end of the day, we are storytellers, giving voice to our stories and to the stories of others who deserve to be heard.  This gives direct access to others into the lives of those, whose stories may otherwise not be heard. In educating others, we aim to develop a more compassionate community of people who can go out into the world and use the stories they connect with to create local and wide-spread change. We want people to be armed with important information so that they can walk through the world with the confidence that is often times needed to confront racism, sexism, transphobia, ableism, anti-blackness, and other forms of oppression faced by those living in the margins of our communities. We are three Women of Color who live and breathe the experience of various forms of marginalization, and in our current social and political climate, it's important that women of color voices are heard, amplified, and supported! It is very important to us to expand into the world of podcasting because it is such a widely followed and intimate outlet for spreading messages that can change the world! Or at least change the way our listeners see the world around them.

 

Why We’re Fundraising

Starting a podcast sounds amazing but it also isn’t cheap and we absolutely need all the help we can get from our followers and supporters! The purpose of starting this campaign is to fundraise for the money we will need to put on a whole YEAR’s worth of podcast episodes! This is such an exciting time in our journey and your contributions will forever hold the legacy of helping us reach bigger audiences for bigger change! We are asking for $8,000 to help us with the start-up costs of this super important project!

 

We're Fundraising For...

 

The cost of studio equipment such as:

  • A Rode Procaster Broadcast Dynamic Vocal Microphone
  • A Rode WS2 Pop Filter/Wind Shield
  • A Rode PSM 1 Shockmount For Podcasters
  • RODE PSA1 Swivel Mount Studio Microphone Boom Arm 
  • Zencastr Call Recording Software so that we can communicate with each other and record our podcasts from our different geographical locations

  • Beats Studio Wireless Over-Ear Headphones

For general operating costs such as:

  • Recording
  • Editing
  • Our Blubrry account which will allow us to host our podcast to places like iTunes.
  • Trademarking our name so that we, as creators, have ownership of our name and content! 

For marketing costs such as:

  • Buying the domain "threetokenbrowngirls.com" so that we can host our podcast content on our own website as well, which keeps our content created and owned by women of color.
  • General social media marketing of our podcast on places like Facebook adds and Google adds. 

 

What If we don’t Raise all of the Money?

Of course, we hope and really do believe we will be able to reach our goal of $8,000 for our start-up costs, but if we don’t, we STILL plan on putting this money towards our dream and goal of podcasting! We are 100% committed to seeing this through by any and all means necessary! Any penny helps us get closer to making this dream a reality.

 

If you Cannot Financially Contribute

We understand that not all of us are able to financially contribute! We have kids, responsibilities, ridiculous costs of living, and we live in that space and understand the very real financial challenges that so many of us face. We would never hold it against you if you just could not contribute money for our podcast goals! With that being said, there are definitely other ways for you to show your support and help us out! Please please please share our campaign with your friends, ask people to donate to us, talk us up, be a champion for us! It’s 100% free to do and takes little effort to click ‘share’! It may take a little more effort to write up a paragraph on how much you love us, but still worth it!!!

 

Closing this Awesome Pitch Out...

We appreciate all and any help we get to make this happen. This project is so important to us and we are ready to jump in and get started on the work it takes to put a podcast together! The three of us have done extensive research on what equipment and programs provide the best quality while being cost effective. We’ve done our research on how to operate something as amazing as a podcast and how to get it out so that people can hear what we have to say! We have all of the knowledge we need, the only thing we’re lacking is the funds to bring this dream into fruition!

Some months ago, we thought of doing a podcast and it honestly seemed impossible. But here we are, taking what we thought was impossible and making it an exciting and great possibility. Please consider donating to our campaign and watch us come alive to educate and engage in compassionate dialogue, social justice education, and advocacy.

story:
Who We Are

We’re creating the Godshead Incidental, a full-cast independent audio drama podcast. The Godshead Incidental is the story of an advice columnist and the letter she never answered, in a city where there may or may not be gods. Characters include an agender thief, an agoraphobic landlord, and the literal god of grammar.

We are raising $3,000 to record, edit, mix, and produce our first season. The majority of this amount will go to per-episode actor and staff salaries, as well as royalties for music and art. The rest will be devoted to recording expenses and hosting for our episodes and website.

The Godshead Incidental explores isolation, anxiety, queer identity, and the myth of becoming an adult, with a few conspiracies and heists along the way. We will begin casting this fall and release our first episode in early 2019. Our first season will be eight 20–40 minute episodes available for free on all major podcasting platforms.

We the co-creators are friends, fellow linguistics majors, and recent graduates who found a home and a calling in independent audio drama. Co-creator Cara is a graduate student at Northwestern’s MA in Sound Arts and Industries program. Co-creator Amy is the co-host of the conversation podcast More Research Required and a panelist on Tortall Recall. She is also the audio editor for Speaking Freely with the ACLU of Pennsylvania.

This is our first foray into creating an audio drama, and we are deeply excited to contribute to the audio drama community. Our favorite thing about independent audio dramas is how creators unabashedly produce cross-genre fiction that centers on characters not often portrayed in mainstream media, and we want to contribute to this new tradition of creating worlds we can see ourselves in.

We realize that supporting a show that doesn’t exist yet is a leap of faith. But we’re asking you to trust us. We’re here, waiting on the other side of the crevasse, ready to catch you. We even brought snacks. Come join us! It’s a leap worth taking.

For additional comments or questions, email us at godsheadincidental@gmail.com!

Our Perks!

You want some perks? We’ve got some perks. Every contributor to this campaign will be forever memorialized in a special thank you section on our website. Other rewards include:

  • Buttons of our show logo designed by Maddie Rode Design.
  • Mp3 audio files of "bird calls" or our best approximations thereof.
  • Handwritten thank-you notes.
  • An opportunity to send The Godshead Incidental's resident advice columnist a letter of your own to be answered in-character in a bonus episode.
  • A PDF excerpt from The Godshead Incidental's classifieds section.
  • The privilege of giving a god your own name or a name of your choosing (subject to our discretion).
  • An exclusive custom photograph of a bird, delivered in an unmarked envelope!

And if all that isn't appealing enough—or if you can't donate but still want to be involved in our campaign...

Participate in the Godshead Bird Gauntlet!

To commemorate our Indiegogo campaign, we’re having four birds battle for fame and glory—and we’re letting you choose the winner! To participate, follow us on Twitter @godsheadpod.

How does it work? Four birds have entered the arena—Hubcaps, Gilbert LaCroix, Anthony Hawk (No Relation), and Webster & Britannica. For the duration of our campaign, we will be posting updates to our Twitter feed as our birds compete in challenges of wits, skill, and combat. Every time we reach a fundraising milestone, we’ll tweet a poll where you can vote for one of our birds to receive a power-up, giving them advantage in the next competition. By the end of our campaign, one bird will be our grand champion.

We present to you our birds:

Hubcaps
Breed: Eurasian tree sparrow
Backstory: Hubcaps was born, raised, lives, and almost died in a junkyard. She’s a real underdog, in that she lives under a dog, due to the junkyard.
Advantage Fighting Terrain: Local used bookstore, Crime & Espionage section
Implement of Choice: Parasol
Favorite Audio Drama Trope: Eating a magic rock so no one else can have it

Gilbert LaCroix
Breed: Snowy white falcon
Backstory: Gilbert LaCroix was trained as an artisanal metalworker in New England, but he recently decided to make a career change and has just completed a 4-month internship with a pack of wolves.
Advantage Fighting Terrain: Ball pit
Implement of Choice: Very shiny fork
Favorite Audio Drama Trope: Sentient plants

Anthony Hawk (no relation)
Breed: Ruffed grouse
Backstory: NO RELATION.
Advantage Fighting Terrain: Hayride
Implement of Choice: Worm on a string
Favorite Audio Drama Trope: A character doing a bad impression of another character

Webster & Britannica
Breed: Pelican and goose
Backstory: Webster & Britannica are from Godshead’s Beacon Hill neighborhood. When they are not engaged in combat with their fellow bird, they can be found reading, exploring nature, and relaxing at home with their partner, Winona Feathersby.
Advantage Fighting Terrain: Decorative fountain
Implement of Choice: Bag of frozen peas
Favorite Audio Drama Trope: Varying degrees of kissing noises

story:
About The Watch and our Crew

The Watch is an audio drama podcast series that follows the stories of three Milwaukee cops on and off the job, as the events they witness and decisions they have to make impact their lives and the lives of those around them. 

Created by Randy Streu and Darby Kern, and written by Kern and Streu, The Watch isn’t your standard police procedural (though thanks to our technical advisor, a retired Milwaukee Police Officer, we’ve tried to keep it as accurate as possible). It is a character-driven story about family, loyalty, and duty. 

Our talented cast includes Katie Leigh (Adventures in Odyssey), Stacey Bradshaw (Lamplighter Theatre), Christian Gill (Jake Muller Adventures), Nato Jacobson (Jonathan Park, The Adventum), Aimee Lilly (Kids Corner), and others. 

The Producers:
Darby Kern is also the creator and writer of The Jake Muller Adventures and has written for several other audio dramas, including Kids’ Corner, Left Behind, Left Behind: The Kids, G.A. Henty Adventures, and others. Darby, whose directorial debut, The Jake Muller Adventures, was nominated for multiple Seneca Awards and won for Best Script and Best New Work, is also directing The Watch.

Randy Streu is a former radio host, multi-published short story writer, and voice actor. His acting credits include audio dramas from Darker Projects, Misfits Audio, and Pendant Audio, an award-winning short film called What You Gotta Do, and several toys including Armogear’s Laser Battle set. He also played FBI Agent David Beck in The Jake Muller Adventures.

Micah Touchet is an award-nominated sound designer. He has worked on The Jake Muller Adventures, audio dramas for the Abide.co app, The Jonathan Park Adventures, and many other commercial projects as producer for NewBirth.

We Need You!

Tannhauser Gate is committed to bringing you quality that you don’t usually find in most free podcast content. As lovers of this medium, we’re also committed to supporting those who make it happen — which means paying our actors.

Our goal of $20,000 will help us create the entire first season of The Watch, including actor fees, studio sessions at the legendary GAP Digital in Wheaton, IL, high-quality sound effects and foley, theme music, etc. 

As a Thank You for making The Watch happen, we have several levels of perks and rewards for you! These include early access to commercial-free episodes, behind-the-scenes content, 1-on-1 virtual meetings with the creators, and more! 

The Impact

We believe that in times like these, it is important to provide positive, entertaining content. Co-creator Darby Kern explains: “So many cop television shows are wrapping things up, or putting an irresponsible spin on law enforcement. The Watch is designed to give the audience an idea of what cops go through in the course of their day, at work, and at home. They have problems like all of us and sometimes they let their problems define them.”

To add to the realism of the show, Tannhauser Gate has engaged the services of our technical advisor, a retired 25-year veteran of the Milwaukee Police Department. 

Risks & Challenges

Let’s be honest: as with any media project, the single biggest hurdle is always going to be finding the audience. We’re in the process of building our social media presence, but I’ll tell you, the greatest asset to finding an audience is word of mouth. Which, what a coincidence, brings us to...

Other Ways You Can Help

We get it! You may be excited about this project, but there’s not a lot you can do financially. That’s okay! You can still be a part of the success and ongoing existence of The Watch. The biggest way you can help, outside funding, is to simply spread the word. If you’re interested, maybe some of your friends are, too! Let them know! 

And if you’re the praying sort, that’s ALWAYS helpful. Our team are big believers in the power of prayer and, even though this is not a ”religious“ or faith-based project, we still pray over both its success and its message. 

 

THANK YOU for your interest in The Watch. If you’d like to get in touch with us, you can do so here or by emailing contact@thewatchpodcast.com

Micah Touchet is an award-nominated sound designer. He has worked on The Jake Muller Adventures, audio dramas for the Abide.co app, The Jonathan Park Adventures, and many other commercial projects as producer for NewBirth.

We Need You!
Tannhauser Gate is committed to bringing you quality that you don’t usually find in most free podcast content. As lovers of this medium, we’re also committed to supporting those who make it happen — which means paying our actors.
Our goal of $20,000 will help us create the entire first season of The Watch, including actor fees, studio sessions at the legendary GAP Digital in Wheaton, IL, high-quality sound effects and foley, theme music, etc. 
As a Thank You for making The Watch happen, we have several levels of perks and rewards for you! These include early access to commercial-free episodes, behind-the-scenes content, 1-on-1 virtual meetings with the creators, and more! 

The Impact
We believe that in times like these, it is important to provide positive, entertaining content. Co-creator Darby Kern explains: “So many cop television shows are wrapping things up, or putting an irresponsible spin on law enforcement. The Watch is designed to give the audience an idea of what cops go through in the course of their day, at work, and at home. They have problems like all of us and sometimes they let their problems define them.”
To add to the realism of the show, Tannhauser Gate has engaged the services of our technical advisor, a retired 25-year veteran of the Milwaukee Police Department. 

Risks & Challenges
Let’s be honest: as with any media project, the single biggest hurdle is always going to be finding the audience. We’re in the process of building our social media presence, but I’ll tell you, the greatest asset to finding an audience is word of mouth. Which, what a coincidence, brings us to...

Other Ways You Can Help
We get it! You may be excited about this project, but there’s not a lot you can do financially. That’s okay! You can still be a part of the success and ongoing existence of The Watch. The biggest way you can help, outside funding, is to simply spread the word. If you’re interested, maybe some of your friends are, too! Let them know! 
And if you’re the praying sort, that’s ALWAYS helpful. Our team are big believers in the power of prayer and, even though this is not a ”religious“ or faith-based project, we still pray over both its success and its message. 
 
THANK YOU for your interest in The Watch. If you’d like to get in touch with us, you can do so here or by emailing contact@thewatchpodcast.com

story:
Do you love Supernatural Creatures?

Want to know more about Contemporary Art, Film & Television? 

I am looking to raise $15000 to allow me the time and resources to create season one of my podcast and nine recorded online seminars. 

Your generous contributions will help me create six episodes of my podcast Supernatural Creature Feature: a queer, feminist take on popular culture & contemporary art. http://kh1art.ca/supernatural-creature-feature-...

The podcast is inspired by a creative non-fiction book I have written about vampires, werewolves, ghosts, demons, witches, and zombies in 21st century art, film & television and a seminar I teach on the topic.

This campaign will also help me raise funds to bring the art history, feminism, interior design history, and popular culture courses I have taught in universities and colleges to you as recorded and live online seminars!

Check out the series of nine recorded online seminars I will be creating with your assistance: http://kh1art.ca/seminars/recorded-online/

Contributing $100 or more gives you access to my 15 live online seminars starting in Sept. 2020 until April 2021: http://kh1art.ca/seminars/live-online/

I have been an adjunct professor in universities and colleges in Canada, the US, and the UK for the last 15 years. I have also taught independent seminars in my living room for the past six years. I received my PhD in the History of Art from University College London in the UK in 2007. http://kh1art.ca/about/

Since there is continually less work for me in academia and I love teaching, I want to shift to teaching independent online seminars for the general public.

Thank you so much for you contributions! I really appreciate your help.

You can also help me out by sharing my campaign: https://igg.me/at/kh1art/x/3195279#/

story:
Who is Spoiler Country?

Kenric Regan - An avid reader and collector of comics and all things geeky in culture. He has worked in a multitude of area including IT, project management, and entrepreneur. Kenrics love of comic books brought him in to the creation of the Spoiler Country Podcast. Where him and his ever-present co-host Johnny bring you all the excitement and retrospective geekery you can handle.

John Horsley - Long time comic book reader and collector. Software Engineer when he has to be. Webcomic creator of y2cl, Inanimate, Sergeant Blinky and his Brigade of Fantastic, Jonly Nonly, Furry Animal Magic, PD Comics, Stolen Ideas, Fuzzy Memory, and more! Currently work on a horror/suspense anthology called "The Eynes Anthology" 

Spoiler Country - John and Kenric come together to form the ultimate in comic based podcasts on a show that was never meant to be about comics but they just can't stop talking about them. 

Why are we doing this?

Doing an on location show in San Diego for Comic-Con isn't cheap! the more funds we raise the more we can do while down there and provide to you!

  • The funds raised here will go to purchase equipment needed for better onsite recording and cover all expenses to get us from Seattle to San Diego and back. 
  • We have worked with some of our friends in the industry to bring you some amazing perks! Some you can only get here on this campaign!
  • If we don't meet our goal, that's ok! All funds raised here will still go to the same thing, it just means we have to cover the rest out of pocket. Either way, we are going to make this happen! 

The end product you are helping to make happen is a series of 5 well produced podcast episodes from the San Diego Comic-Con with reviews and interviews with some great people we meet while down there! We already have some amazing interviews lined up for you all!

The Impact

If you choose to support us you will not be sorry. No one out there is more prolific in their topics and work ethic than we are! 10 months in and we have produced 100 episodes and with each one we strive to make it sound professional and be as entertaining as possible! With your help we can make this even better!

  • Where else can you hear solid conversation on fun topics? You may hear interviews with your favorite creators, but we have conversations that open doors!
  • We have done this same concept at:
    • San Diego Comic-Con 2017
    • San Fransisco Comic-Con 2017
    • Rose City Comic-con 2017
    • Jet City Comic Show 2017
    • Emerald City Comic-con 2018
  • No matter what you have heard before in the world of podcasts, there isn't a show quite like ours!

Every Reward Tier will come with direct links to the episodes produced!

Risks & Challenges

Everything has risks & challenges and our campaign is no different. However, ours is much less. 

  • Baring one of us getting hospitalized, we will be at SDCC and recording episodes!
  • If one of us has to bow out of the trip for any reason, the other will still be going and providing you with as much coverage as possible! The odds of this happening are slim as last year Kenric went with a broken foot!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't support us financially on this but still want to show you love:

  • Share! SHARE SHARE! Let everyone you know know what we are doing and how awesome we are!
  • If you know some awesome creators that will be there get us in touch with them so we can have them on our super special SDCC Show!
  • Share our podcast with your friends as well, more plays means more sponsors, which also helps raise money to cover equipment and expenses!

story:
Short Summary

As the DanceSpeak podcast approaches its 2-year mark it is experiencing a massive growth spurt!  Yes, it is hard to believe that we have essentially grown and spread through word-of-mouth and organic sharing.   With consistency and high-quality guests, we have discovered that the world is our oyster and the potential of this grass-roots podcast in positively impacting those whom love and pursue dance is limitless.  We want to make sure that keep on serving our listeners with powerful episodes and keeping up-to-date on technology.  Moreover, we want to have videos on POINT and to keep delivering content that you love in ways that suit different needs (i.e. short episodes and snippets that are easy to consume on the go for your busy lifestyle).  

 We are opening the door to have listeners and supporters of the podcast partake in our thriving through donating an amount that feels good to you.  Whether it is $1, $3, or $3,000 (hayyy) everything makes a world of difference.  

 Lastly...thank you to everyone who has listened, shared with friends, sent us shout-outs on social media, and have recommended guests and topics.  We APPRECIATE you more that you know!!!

 

What We Need

Our goal is to raise $10,000 to go towards filming interviews, producing content on a consistent (ideally at least weekly) basis, to increase the sound quality, hire PR, updating equipment and purchasing much needed video editing software.  We would also like to be able to pay our team members for the time they put in, as they have kindly been donating their time and we want to keep them on board!

 

The Impact

The goal of the DanceSpeak conversations is to provide free content to educate dancers, choreographers, and teachers whom aspire to reach their highest potential in our field (as well as those in other highly competitive fields).  Our interviews with heavy hitters in the industry provide legacy for those being interviewed, information that can give its listeners more fruitful and long-lasting careers, and ultimately connects us with the human side of the industry. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Keeping up to date and sharing our campaign with your dance fam!
  • Leave us a positive review on iTunes <3

 

THANK YOU!!!!

story:
About Us

Bold as Brass Podcast is an interview podcast where professional musician & host Melissa Brown chats with fellow brass professionals from around the world about their careers. 

We have been on air for a year now and in order to keep the podcast running, and make it a viable part of our working week, we need to raise some money to cover the growing costs of running a podcast like this.

We hope to raise enough money to cover editing and production costs for one year, to build a website, to design merchandise for audience members, to employ someone to work on the show with us mainly transcribing our interviews so that they are further accessible to brass fans.

To find the latest episodes and see what we're about:

Apple podcasts: apple.co/2Ab9vYR 
Google podcasts: bit.ly/3dxquTD
Spotify: spoti.fi/3bhyEOF

What we're trying to achieve

Overall we're aiming to raise £4500 which will last us for a whole year whilst we actively seek a (or more than one) longer term sponsor.

If we raise:

£200 - we can build a website enabling people to find us outside of social media
£500 - we can build a website and organise our first bundle of merchandise for our audience to purchase (not at profit)
£1000 - we can build a website and make our first bundle of merchandise for our audience and produce weekly episodes for half of a year
£2500 - we can do all of the above and pay for the editing and production work for weekly episodes for a whole year
£4500 - we can do all of the above and we can enlist the help of a professional to help transcribe all of our interviews into a blog on our website furthering our audience reach

What's in it for you?

A pledge of £10-25: a shout out on all of our social media platforms

A pledge of £50: a shout out on all of social media platforms, listed thank you on our website when built, acknowledgement in an episode

A pledge of £100+: all of the above, 2 branded badges, and the ability to attend an episode recording and Q&A with host & guest.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people aren't able to contribute financially and we completely understand. Other ways that you can help raise funds and awareness of our project are:

  • Share this forward to all of your brass interested, and music interested, friends
  • Tell people about our show
  • Listen to our show

We know our podcast has a great audience and lots of people who consume and enjoy our content. We aim for Bold as Brass Podcast to remain free to access and listen to. If we do not meet our target, we will continue to produce these episodes at cost to ourselves (as we have done up until this point).

story:
Epilogue:

A narrative nonfiction podcast about suicide, grief, mental illness, and resilience

My name is Galen McCaw, and on January 2nd of 2018, I woke up to learn that my Dad, after decades of struggling with mental illness, took his own life. I found myself struggling to connect with others in the months afterwards, wary of the strange silence that often followed the few words I managed to find, and exhausted at the thought of trying to fill that silence. After all, what do you say to someone who’s suffered that kind of loss? Or after you’ve suffered it?

 

I discovered the power of listening when I attended my first support group for people who have lost loved ones to suicide. For two hours, those in attendance offered beloved memories, sorrow, laughter, anger, regret, and joy to the others around them in communion. I left wanting to find ways of connecting with and learning from others who carry loss, in their own way, in the wake of suicide. And there are so many. Based on the statistics we are able to collect, someone around the world dies by their own hand every 40 seconds.

 

We hope to honor those who have passed, ourselves, and everyone else out there bearing grief on a daily basis by telling stories about the very human experience of loss. Epilogue will be a non-fiction storytelling podcast about people experiencing suicide loss, grief, and mental illness, and ultimately the resilience it takes to continue on in the face of these struggles. Each story will be told in one roughly hour long episode, in a long form narrative format. 

 

Who We Are

 

 

I met my collaborators, Laura Bargfeld and Carolyn McKee, in film school at The University of Arizona. I am an Emmy-awarded sound recordist and editor working in documentary, commercial, and narrative film production. Laura received her BA in creative writing with a minor in film and television, and has experience in creative nonfiction, documentary film editing, and producing. Carolyn is a filmmaker, visual artist, writer, and educator; she earned a BFA film and television, and a BA in philosophy.

 

We grew together over the course of many creative projects, and have become steadfast supporters of each other throughout our own mental health struggles. With every project, and every conversation we share, we feel more convinced of the power of storytelling to connect and heal. Our collective skill set and lived experience give us the tools to create a platform for these stories to be shared and explored widely, and we want to make sure the project isn’t something we do alone. It’s about all of us, the diversity of perspectives and experiences we hope to represent, and including communities outside our own.

 

Where We’re At

 

Right now, our goal is to raise enough money to produce a pilot episode and to continue moving forward with our mission of creating a series. Long form nonfiction storytelling is time and resource intensive, which is why we need to raise money to fund that process. We will be working with composers to create original music like what you heard in our trailer, as well as with consultants who will help sell advertising, form partnerships, and market the podcast.

 

Since we began development in October 2018, we’ve recorded over 50 hours of interviews with 20 subjects to hone in on the identity of the project. But that's just the start. Ultimately, we intend to create a collection of stories that represent the reach that suicide and mental illness have across demographics, time, and place. But before we do that, what we need are the resources to prove our concept, to dig deeper and spend the time to tell one story in a way that respects its complexity.

 

What We Need

 

We’ve identified the following production and development costs which will enable us to move forward with our pilot episode and continue our development process:

 

Software/recording equipment: $3,070

Travel: $3,000

Consulting: $2,025

Website fees/transcription services: $1,400

Total: $9,495

 

Contingency: Professional budgeting in creative media projects will include a percentage of total budget (usually 5-10%) to account for unforeseen expenses and variations in cost of resources

%5 of Total: $474.75 (Rounded to $505)

 

TOTAL GOAL $10,000

 

Where We’re Going

 

Once we have a trailer and pilot episode, our next step is to pitch the project to community mental health providers, non-profits, and private companies. Our goal will be to take on sponsors and partner organizations who can help support the project’s development and guide its growth. With local branches of the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention and the National Alliance on Mental Illness, numerous healthcare providers and mental health non-profits, and a vibrant art scene in our community, there is an amazing culture of support in which a creative project like ours can thrive. With the proper foundation, a storytelling project like this will fill a real need for people experiencing mental illness, suicide loss, and grief.

 

Get in Touch

 

Please reach out directly if you have any ideas about how you can be a part of our project, what the project might look like or how it can integrate with your work, art, or research, or if you have any specific questions we haven’t covered!

 

Contact:

galen@epiloguestories.org

story:
What is Who Knows?

Hello! Thank you so much for taking the time to check out Who Knows?

My name is Taylor Dankovich and I am a sound designer, podcast producer and audio engineer based in Greensboro, North Carolina. I love to create entertaining work that also reaches people mentally and emotionally. I am motivated and inspired by creativity and innovation, self-improvement, and helping others in every way I can.

My goal is to bring awareness to the importance of mental health and to remove the stigma surrounding mental health struggles.

I have struggled mentally and emotionally my entire life. In my teen years, I would freely express my feelings to other people only to notice their discomfort, as if they were afraid of emotions. It left me feeling as if I was the only one dealing with intense negative emotions and overwhelming confusion. That all changed when I left college and discovered that many people felt the same way but were just not openly talking about it. I thought to myself “Imagine what it would be like if we started confessing to others that we don’t have it all together? We could learn a lot from each other.”

I decided to use my skills in audio and my passion for mental health advocacy to create Who Knows?

Who Knows? is a podcast that works to promote mental health awareness, self-love and creating your own normal. It explores life in a way that is transparent, honest and curious.

We have lively and honest discussion about all the messy, confusing and scary stuff all of us go through. We talk about both the good and the bad because “the bad” is just stuff that’s a little more complicated. It’s about learning and growing, tearing down walls, opening up, asking questions and giving our best advice.

We’re here to remind you that you’re not alone and that mental health matters.

Our Story So Far

Since Who Knows? began in 2017, three great podcast seasons have been brought to life covering 25 different topics such as Gender, Friendship, Small Business Management, and Body Positivity. The stories of 29 amazing and inspiring people who share my passion for mental health advocacy have been told. We have grown our listener numbers, our social media platforms and, most importantly, we have begun to build a community of individuals seeking to make conversation about mental health a part of everyday life.  

The moments of success have shown that there is a desire for content that is relatable, not only to those who struggle with diagnosed mental health issues, but to anyone who’s ever felt a sense of unbelonging and are searching for a community that understands them. People are looking for entertaining content that promotes personal growth and learning through a real-life lens. They want to hear real stories from honest people. They want advice from those who are succeeding in areas where they are struggling. They want to feel less alone.

I am so proud of what Who Knows? has begun to accomplish as a podcast, but when I think about the future of Who Knows?, I dream of extending beyond the podcasting platform.

More Than a Podcast

I started this podcast because I am a person who needs this podcast.  From conversations with friends, co-workers, and listeners of Who Knows?, I know there are others who are looking for more mental health-based content that feels real and relatable.

Mental Health exists as an essential part of everyday life. Instagram, YouTube, blogs, podcasts and other media platforms have also become an essential part of everyone’s daily life as sources of entertainment, inspiration, education, community and emotional support, with creators becoming mentors and friends.

Who Knows? is that mentor and friend, and I want to be able to reach our friends wherever they are and find new ones in more places. Who Knows? can be more than a podcast, it can be a mental health entertainment media community.

I want to create more avenues for people to consume content that is rooted in self-love and mental health advocacy. Content that helps people to gain information, promotes personal growth and offers advice for those who are on their own journey in life. I want to empower others to face their fears and be who they are.

My mission is to show that emotional and mental health struggles are a part of life, but they do not have to prevent you from living.

What We Need

The goal is to take Who Knows? from a mental health podcast to a mental health-based media company. Growing our audience is essential to achieving this goal, and to do that we need to offer more content in more places to expand our reach.

In its current form, Who Knows? exists in podcasting, social media, and Patreon. As I begin branching out into other platforms, I want to offer weekly videos and weekly blog posts. This is only the beginning of what I ultimately hope to offer at the height of the company’s existence, but with your donation, this is where I hope to start.

Making this a reality requires me to maintain total focus on creating these additional forms of content. Creating is a full-time job and currently I am doing it for only $20 a month. $5,000 will be a steppingstone for me to begin to make Who Knows? my full-time job by spending 100% of my work time creating:

  • Biweekly Podcast Episodes
  • Daily Social Media Content
  • Weekly Videos
  • Weekly Blog Posts

Once this content begins to circulate, my hope is that our community numbers will begin to grow, the work will begin to generate revenue on its own through ad sales and additional Patreon subscribers, and Who Knows? will begin to go from a dream to a fully functioning business. Your donations will help to begin a new career path for me, the creation of an array of content that is based in the importance of self-love and mental health, and more visibility for those who struggle with their mental health.

This podcast is the first thing I think about when I wake up in the morning and the last thing I think about when I go to bed. Working on this show has helped me to improve and explore my own mental health. Its moments of success have shown that I am capable of more than I ever saw possible for myself. I love the work that I do and I am so proud of what this show has become so far, but I want to do so much more. I see a vision for growth and longevity for Who Knows? that goes beyond me and my home office. Eventually I hope to hire a team of creators to work with me, to be able to offer merchandise and live performances, and so much more.

What You Get

If you are able to contribute any amount to this vision, you will be helping make a dream a reality. The countless hours of work, sleepless nights, and weeks of anxiety will have been worth it for me knowing that there are people out there who see the value in mental health advocacy, visibility, as well as the importance of the work of artists and creators who bring entertaining, heartfelt and meaningful content to life. 

 

If you are able to contribute:

 

  • $15 or more, you will receive a very special thank you via our social media!

 

  • $30 or more, you will receive a special thank you via our social media, as well as a shoutout on the podcast!

 

  • $50 or more, you will receive a special thank you via our social media, a shoutout on the podcast, and your name will appear at the end of every one of our videos that we create!

 

  • $100 or more, you will receive a special thank you via our social media, a shoutout on the podcast, your name will appear at the end of every one of our videos that we create, and you will receive an exclusive thank you card as well as one of our Who Knows? Buttons!

 

  • $500 or more, you will receive a special thank you via our social media, a shoutout on the podcast, your name will appear at the end of every one of our videos that we create, you will receive an exclusive thank you card as well as one of our Who Knows? Buttons, and once we are able to create more merchandise such as stickers, mugs, hats and T-shirts, you will be the first to receive every one of our products free of charge in a very special care package!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you so much for your time and consideration! Please be sure to share this campaign with everyone you know so that we can have a greater chance of reaching our goal!

  • If you would like to learn more about the show, you can visit our website at whoknowspod.com
  • If you listen to the show and like what you hear, you can support us even further by joining our monthly contribution subscribers via Patreon at patreon.com/whoknowspod

If you are passionate about the goals we are trying to accomplish, but monetary assistance is not within your means, that's OK! There are so many free ways that you can help Who Knows? grow and reach people who need it.

  • Follow us on Instagram and Twitter @whoknowspod
  • Like our page on Facebook at Who Knows?
  • Tell your friends and family about us and what we are trying to accomplish so they can either donate or continue to spread the word about us even further.
